entry.title: Re: Order Confirmation change Output type
entry.content:
SAP’s output determination for Order Confirmation Change is notoriously sensitive to which fields are considered “relevant for change.” Not all field modifications will trigger the output type automatically. SAP uses a combination of Change indicator logic, Field catalog configuration and Processing routines tied to the output type. Only changes to fields that are flagged as relevant for output regeneration will trigger the output type

To find out what controls are implemented in your system, Go to transaction NACE → Application V1 (Sales) → Output Types → Select your output type (e.g., BA00 or custom). Check the Processing Routines section. The Program and Form Routine define which fields are monitored.

You can also review SAP Note 395569 for a checklist of change-relevant fields

entry.title: Need to validate the Housebank of Invoices during manual payment in Post Outgoing Payments app
entry.content:
Hi All,

We are working on implementing a custom validation to ensure that during manual payments, house bank selected matches the house bank used in the reference vendor invoice selected for payment. 

To achieve this, we implemented a Custom Logic enhancement using BAdi FIN_ACDOC_ITEM_VALDATION.

This logic compares the house bank from the current journal entry line with one used in the reference invoice, using the standard CDS view I_JournalEntryItem

We need to block payments if the house bank/ account id used does not match the original invoice's house bank to prevent accounting mismatches.

Our requirement is:

  1. Is BAdi FIN_ACDOC_ITEM_VALDATION triggered during manual payments posted via the Post Outgoing Payments App?
  2. If not triggered, is there an alternate enhancement point that support this validation.
  3. What is the recommended way to validate or restrict the house bank used in manual payments with reference to invoice data in Public cloud?

Thanks & Regards,

entry.title: Re: GL accounts by item level
entry.content:
Buenas dias,
You could make a formatted search, but then you should use that on all documents in the process.

SELECT 
    CASE 
        WHEN $[$38.1.0] = 'A00001' THEN '8100' 
        ELSE $[$38.29.0] 
    END

 

You really should consider using the advanced gl determination. It makes the booking process much more flexible. The wizard will create the rules according your current standard determination. Try it in a test environment!

Saludos, Andy

I would suggest to use scheduling agreement Procurement - Sales integrated scenario. Please check the documents (set up instructions) included in 3NR and BMR scope items. entry.title: Send email notification when an existing Termination date changes
entry.content:
We already have an email notification which is sent to a specific group of people via an email address when an employee (who meets specific criteria) is terminated.   This is already working perfectly.   However, we now want to create a separate email notification, which is sent to the same group of people if the Termination Date changes.

For example, Fred Bloggs has been terminated with an effective date in the future of, say 15 August 2025.   A notification is sent to a specific group of people to let them know of the forthcoming termination action.   However, that Termination Date might be brought forward or pushed out to a different date, say 30 August 2025.   When the Termination Date is changed, we want an additional email notification to be sent to the same group of people to let them know there's been a Termination Date change.   The email itself would simply provide the latest Termination Date for that employee, so nothing complex like previous Termination Date and current Termination Date.

I've attempted this numerous times, but the rule created to trigger the workflow (email notification) doesn't trigger.   Has anyone else done this successfully and if so, how did you achieve it?  Some other notable points:

Our Termination Date is configured as part of our employmentInfo HRIS element.   But when we change the Termination Date we essentially Edit the event date which relates to the Termination event directly from within Job Info History.  We then go into the Employment Details portlet (which is NOT effective-dated) and adjust the Payroll End Date and Last Date Worked dates accordingly.

entry.title: Re: PM Order cannot control budget from the WBS element o...
entry.content:
In Public Cloud, PM Orders (account assignment type F) are not inherently budget-controlled via WBS elements. Even if a WBS is assigned to the Functional Location, the PR/PO created from the PM Order doesn’t inherit the WBS for budget availability control. The system checks budget only if the WBS is directly assigned in the account assignment of the PR/PO (e.g., type P).

You can try with some possible below workarounds

  • Instead of standard PM Orders, use Project Orders (account assignment type P). Assign the WBS directly to the order so that all commitments and actuals are tracked against the project budget. This enables Availability Control (AVC) to monitor budget consumption
  • If you're using Developer Extensibility, you can build logic to Automatically derive the WBS from the Functional Location. Inject it into the PR/PO during creation.

entry.title: SAP SUCCESSFACTORS BUG REPORT
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community, please find the Details of bug highlighted below. Let me know if you have a Fix!

Details of the BUG:

This Bug has been identified in Change Job and Compensation Information for...  Transaction which only selects the Job information and not the Compensation Information. Ideally, this should also select Job and Compensation Information which is the core purpose of the transaction. But the following transaction only selects the Job information and not the Compensation Information.

 

There are separate transactions Change Job Information for... and Change Compensation for... transactions which are used for changing Job Information and compensation information separately.

Hi,

I have two different CAP Apps. 

My goal is to host them on the same PostgreSQl instance in two diffferent schemas

Therefor I added in my db/schema.cds file the annotation

namespace de.test.cap_schema;
using {cuid} from '@sap/cds/common';
@schema: 'schema1'
entity DemoData  : cuid{
       name            : String;
};

In mta.yaml I added the schema as well

resources:
    - name: pgdb
      type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
      parameters:
          service: postgresql-db
          service-plan: trial
          config:
              schema: "schema1"

When I deploy the deployer app for the database, it tries to delete all files from the default database, which was deployed with the first app. The @SCHEMA annoation for second app seems to be useless...

 

Any ideas?
Jens

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4 Hana public Expected Delivery Notification Alert for a Requestor
entry.content:
Hello,

Can you please clarify "They would like the requestor to receive a notification about the expected delivery date for an item that is due to arrive."? What should be the trigger for a notification in this case? For this one "if no receipt has been made after a certain period, a follow-up notification should be sent.", I would suggest to think about event handling in BTP. The overdue PO items are shown in Monitor Purchase Order Items app, so when there is an item set as overdue in that app, this means an event in the system, which can be used to trigger a notification from BTP.

Another variant will be to explore the Manage Situation Type - Extended app with which you can create your own custom situation type.

entry.title: Uploading attachment with cap-js/attachment plugins but via External App/Postman
entry.content:
If anyone here are struggling uploading attachments via external app to cap-js/attachments, I am writing this blog to showcase how to upload attachments on the plugins via external applications.

The blog shall include:

1. Pre-requisites

2. Example 1. via Postman

3. Example 2. via External App (React)

 

1. Pre-requisites: cap-js/attachment 

You have extended your current entity for example:

Attachment entity accepts the following field below:

The fields above are important and to be used for your JSON Body parameters (can leave status as blank as it uses 'Unscanned' as default). See below sample scenarios on how we can upload attachment:

2. Example 1. (via Postman)

**Other API tools are doable

In this case, we require an existing entry in our table/fiori app.

Here are the steps:

1. Retrieve a single entry from your entity, copy the link and add /YourAttachmentEntity that you extended. (On my case, discount_attachment)

Ex:

2. Follow the entity fields then replicate it, then attach your desired parameters on the body as raw - JSON format

(Convert your file to base64. In my case I attached an image, png format)

3. Send the request, you will see that it responded successfully. Go back to your Fiori app to verify if the attachment reflected:

 

3. Example 2. (External App)

I have developed a React App for POC purposes. In this scenario, the data should be created first, then update that same entry using the ID, then upload the attachment via HTTP POST.  Let's breakdown:

1. Upload attachment as input='file', bind it in form data including all the parameters:

2. Build your logic for your initial creation. 

Note: My .ENV variable contains the base odata URL (/odata/v4/......, not the whole http url)

3. Convert the file from input='file' to base64 via JS logic, then bind the OData URL with your entity keys and the HTTP body parameters (refer to Attachment Entity fields and Postman example above).  then proceed OData call

My form will display a successful message and it should reflect on the database/fiori app as well.

Conclusion: 

This blog demonstrates how SAP CAP can interface seamlessly with external apps to enhance attachment handling across varied use cases. By abstracting the upload and retrieval logic via an API layer, the approach supports modular features in both admin dashboards and customer-facing applications. Despite initial challenges around payload structuring and authorization, the solution remains scalable, secure, and adaptable to different frontend contexts.

Let me know if you have any further questions or wish to communicate, just comment below the comment section.

entry.title: Exposing SAP S4 Onprem data to external System || Odata Service || BTP || Destination-Connectivity
entry.content:
Prerequisites from BTP Side

  1. SAP BTP Account
    • Access to SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) with appropriate entitlements.
  2. SAP Cloud Connector Setup
    • SAP Cloud Connector installed and configured to connect your on-premise S/4HANA system to SAP BTP.
    • Destination configured in BTP cockpit pointing to your on-premise system.
  3. Connectivity Service and Destination Service
    • SAP BTP Connectivity service and destination service instance on the BTP account.
  4. Cloud Foundry Environment
    • Cloud Foundry space set up in your BTP subaccount to deploy the application.

Use Case:

Lets take a simple use case for creating a RAP service on S4, which is a wrapper API call on the reprocess IDOC function module.

For this we will create a RAP service on the S4 box, than activate the service with the /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and activate the ICF Node as well.

Note: In this blog we will not go through the steps of setting cloud connector and destination on the BTP account. We will assume that destination with cloud connector setup is already available on the BTP. 

Step 1: Create and activate the RAP service on the S4 Box.

 We will create a unmanaged rap scenario with custom entity and than we will create a service definition and top of service definition we will create service binding.

Lets create the class for the query implementation.

 

We are calling the FM to reprocess the idoc and checking the relevant table to get the latest reprocessed idoc status for the same.

Now we will create a service definition and service binding for the custom entity created.

Service Definition

And overall project will look something like this.

Here i have created two types of service bindings v2 and v4 but we will be using only v2 for this.

So overall we created below 4 artifacts.

1. Custom entity

2. Class

3. Service definition

4. Service binding

Now to test the service we will publish the service first and than call the generated url

if you see the image, i have published the service and after publish we also got the custom entity that we have created, click on the service url and it will open in browser asking for authentication of S4 user id and password.

Once the authentication is successful you should be able to see this.

Now lets open the SAP GUI so that i can show you the ICF node activation, which is generally taken care by basis team.

Open the Tcode: /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE

Here you can find your activated service binding and make sure all components of the service looks as it is in the image.

Assuming cloud connector and destination is setup on BTP.

With this we completed the S4 box setup, now its ready to communicate with other external systems.

Step 2: Creating the Destination service and Connectivity service on the BTP Account.

Login in to BTP account and lets create 2 service instances with service keys.

1. Destination service, this will help us to get the destination details, Destination service gets all the registered destinations on the BTP, from which we can filter out the destination that is up for our S4 onprem box.

Destination service will give us all the relevant things like user id passwd, location and etc. for that destination.

Service key for the destination service

2. Connectivity Service, Since we are trying to get the data out of onprem system we will have to use connectivity service from btp, which will provide us proxies, this proxies will be use to call the onprem odata url.

It is important to paste here the service keys for better understanding since we will be using many things from the service key into our application

Step 3: Lets create a python application to call the onprem service.

Important things to consider here.

By using destination and connectivity service we cannot test the application on local system, we will have to deploy our app on CF to test the same.

We will use the flask requests and certain other libraries for the python programming

file: .env file to store all the secrets this secrets are from the service keys only.

 

File: Requirements.txt

File: Runtime.txt

python-3.11.*

file: manifest.yaml

file:idocapis.py (should be same as mentioned in Manifest.yml file

Load all the required libraries.

define the function to get the token

Define function to get the list of all destinations on the BTP

Define the function to construct the URL for the odata call

Define function to get token for the connectivity service

Define function to call the odata service with connectivity things

Now lets define the final route in flask to call this service

One thing to note here the RESOURCE variable will depend on the destination url of the onprem that is setup on BTP.

 

STEP 4: Deployment

Lets deploy the app on the CF by pushing the app to the cloud foundry from the BAS

Use command cf push after successful authentication for your cloud foundry space.

After the deployment on the cloud we can get the url that is generated on the cloud.

Testing the application:

Lets create a small python program to call this API in local now to test it.

You should get response coming from your S4 onPrem system.

Thanks for staying till the end!!!😊

entry.title: CPI Buttons: Helpful Tools for SAP Integration Suite Developer
entry.content:
In my previous blog post, I introduced an extension called PD Where Used, which helped SAP Integration Suite developers quickly identify where ProcessDirect endpoints were consumed.

Since then, I’ve gathered feedback and added new features that help integration consultants save time, especially when dealing with large numbers of iFlows. The result is a new, enhanced extension:

CPI Buttons

CPI Buttons is an extension that combines several small but helpful tools to make working with the SAP Integration Suite more efficient. It includes the original PD Where Used functionality along with new features for navigation, documentation, and artifact discovery.

Why CPI Buttons?

Many daily tasks in integration projects are repetitive and time-consuming:

  • Tracing ProcessDirect usage across iFlows

  • Tracing JMS usage across iFlows

  • Exporting artifact metadata for documentation

  • Finding out which iFlow corresponds to a known endpoint

This extension adds a few non-intrusive buttons directly to the Integration Suite interface to streamline these actions.

Features

Where Used (PD and JMS)

This feature appears in the iFlow Design page and allows you to scan:

  • PD Where Used: Lists other iFlows that consume current flow’s ProcessDirect endpoints.

  • JMS Where Used: Lists other iFlows that send or receive messages using the same JMS queues.

All flow names in the results are clickable, allowing you to directly navigate to the corresponding iFlow.

 

 

Export Integration Content to Excel

You’ll find two “Export to Excel” buttons:

  • In the Design screen: Exports all design-time iFlows with technical and business metadata

  • In the Monitoring screen: Exports deployed artifacts, grouped by type (IntegrationFlow, ValueMapping, etc.)

These exports help you with documentation, audit preparation, or simply analyzing your integration landscape.

 

 

Endpoint Search Bar (Monitoring Page)

Support projects often suffer from inconsistent naming conventions between iFlow names and endpoint URLs. It’s common to know an endpoint (from logs, alerts, tickets) but not which iFlow it's connected to.

This search bar, added to the Monitoring page, allows you to paste any known endpoint and shows the corresponding iFlow instantly via a toast popup.

Only exact matches are considered to avoid false positives. After pasting the endpoint to the searchbar, you should push the enter button.

 

Platform Compatibility

CPI Buttons has been tested and works reliably on both SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Foundry) and Neo environments. 

Installation

For Chrome: Install directly from Chrome Web Store.

Once installed, the new buttons will appear automatically in the relevant SAP Integration Suite screens.

Feedback

If you find CPI Buttons useful, feel free to:

  • Share with your team

  • Connect with me on LinkedIn

  • Comment on SAP Community with suggestions or feature requests

Emre Anil Kucuk

entry.title: Re: How to update properties of DMS repo
entry.content:
Hello Dan,

It depends on what you are using to connect to the DMS.

From the screenshot you send, it looks like you are working with postman.
If you are using Postman, you would have to PUT https://{{endpoint}}/rest/v2/repositories/(Repository ID) and hit send.

If you work with the SAP API, you would have to select PUT /rest/v2/repositories/{id} and in the parameters part, add the id of the repository you want to modify and in the body include the change you need and hit run.
In my case, to make the change with PUT, I added to the body, all the json of my repository, with the modified part.

I hope this has helped you.

Regards.
Santiago.

entry.title: A Step-by-Step Guide to Implementing an Excel Upload Button in a Fiori App using RAP
entry.content:
Live Demo

Here is a short video demonstrating the final Excel upload functionality in action.

 

For this demonstration, I've built a simple RAP application with a V4 UI. The application features an "Employee" table with three fields. The base of the application was created using the RAP generator, and I've also included early numbering logic for the Employee ID.

Step 1: Create a Fiori Project

To begin, create a new SAP Fiori project using the List Report template. This will serve as the foundation for our application.

Step 2: Add a Custom Button

With the project set up, the next step is to add a custom button. You can do this by using the open guided development feature. From there, choose the option to Add a Custom Action to a Page Using Extensions. Follow the prompts in the guide to insert the necessary code snippets for the "Excel Upload" button.

 

 

or 

Step 2: Configure the manifest.json File

The manifest.json file is the application descriptor, defining its structure, data sources, and routing. To add the "Excel Upload" button, you need to modify this file to define a custom action and extend the standard List Report controller with our custom logic.

You can either use the "Add a Custom Action to a Page Using Extensions" option in the guided development tool or update the manifest.json file directly with the following configuration. Pay close attention to the controlConfiguration and extends sections, which are key to enabling this functionality.

{
  "_version": "1.53.0",
  "sap.app": {
    "id": "uploadempexcel",
    "type": "application",
    "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties",
    "applicationVersion": {
      "version": "0.0.1"
    },
    "title": "{{appTitle}}",
    "description": "{{appDescription}}",
    "resources": "resources.json",
    "sourceTemplate": {
      "id": "@sap/generator-fiori:lrop",
      "version": "1.18.2",
      "toolsId": "f8a70d19-c3d7-40bf-9b4b-03ba34f86143"
    },
    "dataSources": {
      "mainService": {
        "uri": "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zui_upload_emp_o4/srvd/sap/zui_upload_emp_o4/0001/",
        "type": "OData",
        "settings": {
          "annotations": ["annotation"],
          "localUri": "localService/mainService/metadata.xml",
          "odataVersion": "4.0"
        }
      }
    }
  },
  "sap.ui5": {
    "flexEnabled": true,
    "dependencies": {
      "minUI5Version": "1.114.9",
      "libs": {
        "sap.m": {},
        "sap.ui.core": {},
        "sap.fe.templates": {}
      }
    },
    "routing": {
      "routes": [
        {
          "pattern": ":?query:",
          "name": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList",
          "target": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList"
        }
      ],
      "targets": {
        "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList": {
          "type": "Component",
          "id": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList",
          "name": "sap.fe.templates.ListReport",
          "options": {
            "settings": {
              "contextPath": "/ZC_UPLOAD_EMP",
              "controlConfiguration": {
                "@com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1.LineItem": {
                  "actions": {
                    "uploadExcelController.controller": {
                      "press": ".extension.uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController.uploadExcel",
                      "visible": true,
                      "enabled": true,
                      "requiresSelection": false,
                      "text": "Upload Excel"
                    }
                  }
                }
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    },
    "extends": {
      "extensions": {
        "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
          "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
            "controllerName": "uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Step 3: Create a Fragment for the Pop-up Screen

You'll need to create a fragment in the ext folder. This fragment will define the pop-up screen that appears when a user clicks the "Excel Upload" button.

 

<core:FragmentDefinition xmlns="sap.m" xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" xmlns:upload="sap.m.upload">
    <Dialog id="uploadDialogSet" title="Excel Upload">
        <content>
            <upload:UploadSet
                id="uploadSet"
                maxFileNameLength="200"
                fileTypes="xlsx, xls"
                afterItemAdded=".onAfterItemAdded"
                afterItemRemoved=".onAfterItemRemoved"
                uploadEnabled="true"
                />
        </content>
        <!-- CORRECTED: Changed from <buttons> to <beginButton> and <endButton> -->
        <beginButton>
            <Button id="idUploadB" text="Upload" press=".onUploadPress" type="Emphasized" enabled="false"/>
        </beginButton>
        <endButton>
            <Button id="idCancelB" text="Cancel" press=".onCloseDialog" />
        </endButton>
    </Dialog>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Step 4: Implement the Controller Logic

The main logic for handling the file upload is contained within the uploadExcelController.controller.js file. You can adapt the code below for your own application. Make sure to adjust the file name and payload column names to fit your specific needs.

sap.ui.define(
  [
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension",
    "sap/m/MessageToast",
    "sap/ui/core/Fragment",
    "xlsx",
  ],
  function (ControllerExtension, MessageToast, Fragment, XLSX) {
    "use-strict";

    return ControllerExtension.extend(
      "uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController",
      {
        _pDialog: null,
        _file: null,

        uploadExcel: function () {
          if (!this._pDialog) {
            this._pDialog = Fragment.load({
              id: this.base.getView().getId(),
              name: "uploadempexcel.ext.fragment.uploadExcelFragment",
              controller: this,
            }).then(
              function (oDialog) {
                this.base.getView().addDependent(oDialog);
                return oDialog;
              }.bind(this)
            );
          }

          this._pDialog.then(
            function (oDialog) {
              oDialog.open();
              oDialog.getContent()[0].removeAllItems();
              this._file = null;
              var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
              if (oUploadButton) {
                oUploadButton.setEnabled(false);
              }
            }.bind(this)
          );
        },

        onCloseDialog: function () {
          this._pDialog.then(function (oDialog) {
            oDialog.close();
          });
        },

        onAfterItemAdded: function (oEvent) {
          this._file = oEvent.getParameter("item").getFileObject();
          if (this._file) {
            MessageToast.show(
              "File '" + this._file.name + "' is ready for upload."
            );
          }
          this._pDialog.then(
            function (oDialog) {
              var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
              if (oUploadButton) {
                oUploadButton.setEnabled(!!this._file);
              }
            }.bind(this)
          );
        },

        onAfterItemRemoved: function (oEvent) {
          this._file = null;
          this._pDialog.then(function (oDialog) {
            var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
            if (oUploadButton) {
              oUploadButton.setEnabled(false);
            }
          });
          MessageToast.show("File removed.");
        },

        onUploadPress: function () {
          if (!this._file) {
            MessageToast.show("Please select a file first.");
            return;
          }

          var oReader = new FileReader();
          oReader.onload = function (e) {
            try {
              var data = e.target.result;
              var workbook = XLSX.read(data, { type: "buffer" });
              var sheetName = workbook.SheetNames[0];
              var excelData = XLSX.utils.sheet_to_row_object_array(
                workbook.Sheets[sheetName]
              );

              if (excelData.length > 0) {
                this._callOdataService(excelData);
              } else {
                MessageToast.show("No data found in the Excel file.");
              }
            } catch (error) {
              MessageToast.show("Error reading Excel file: " + error.message);
            }
          }.bind(this);

          oReader.readAsArrayBuffer(this._file);
        },

        _callOdataService: function (excelData) {
          try {
            // --- START: FINAL CORRECTED CODE ---
            // Get the main OData V4 model from the view.
            var oModel = this.base.getView().getModel();

            // Create a ListBinding directly for the entity set of the List Report.
            // The path MUST match the 'contextPath' in your manifest.json for the List Report target.
            var oListBinding = oModel.bindList("/ZC_UPLOAD_EMP");
            // --- END: FINAL CORRECTED CODE ---

            if (!oListBinding) {
              // This error is now highly unlikely to occur.
              throw new Error(
                "Could not create a ListBinding for the path /ZC_UPLOAD_EMP."
              );
            }

            excelData.forEach(function (rowData) {
              // IMPORTANT: Make sure your Excel column headers match exactly
              var oPayload = {
                //EmpID: rowData.EmployeeID.toString(), auto generated by Early Numbering in RAP Application
                Empname: rowData.EmployeeName.toString(),
                Contact: rowData.Contact.toString(),
              };
              // The create operation is performed on the ListBinding instance.
              oListBinding.create(oPayload);
            });

            MessageToast.show("Uploading " + excelData.length + " records...");

            // The model holds the batch queue, so we submit the changes on the model.
            oModel
              .submitBatch("$auto")
              .then(
                function () {
                  MessageToast.show("Data uploaded successfully.");
                  this.base.getExtensionAPI().refresh(); // Refresh the table to show new data
                  this.onCloseDialog();
                }.bind(this)
              )
              .catch(function (oError) {
                MessageToast.show("Error during upload: " + oError.message);
              });
          } catch (error) {
            MessageToast.show("Error processing data: " + error.message);
          }
        },
      }
    );
  }
);

Dependencies

Before you can run the application, you'll need to install the necessary dependencies. You can do this by running the following commands in your terminal.

npm i ui5-tooling-modules
npm i xlsx

We also need to update your ui5.yaml file by adding the following custom tasks.

builder:
customTasks:
- name: ui5-tooling-modules-task
afterTask: replaceVersion
- name: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
afterMiddleware: compression

Conclusion

By following these steps, you can add a fully functional Excel upload feature to your SAP Fiori application. This enhancement provides a more convenient way for users to handle bulk data uploads, ultimately improving the user experience. I have also prepared a demo Excel file with sample data that you can use for testing purposes.

entry.title: Re: In CN41N report incoming Payment & Outgoing payment n...
entry.content:
CN41N report in SAP does not display actual incoming or outgoing payments, even if all the steps (PR, PO, GR, IR, payment) are completed. CN41N pulls data from Controlling (CO) tables, such as RPSCO, which include costs, commitments, and budgets. Payments, however, are pure FI postings (e.g., via F-53 or automatic payment runs) and are stored in FI tables like BSEG, not CO. Since payments don’t generate CO documents, they aren’t reflected in PS reports like CN41N.

What you can do instead is to use FI Reports like FBL1N or FAGLL03, for Payment Tracking. Filter by WBS element if it’s populated via substitution or manual entry.

Use FI substitution rules to populate the WBS element in accounting documents. This allows you to track payments against WBS in FI reports, even if CN41N doesn’t show them.  

If you want to merge both CO & FI data to show the values against WBS elements, then, you need to go for custom validation at the ALV level of CN41N to insert payment data

Hi

 

Is this about a transaction you do to another bank account (outgoing payment) that was returned, or is it a transaction to your bank account, which was returned to the sending bank (incoming payment) ?

 

 

Here my assumption, because I do not have all information which is needed:

Your bank is treating returns as reversals, assigning the refunding party as the creditor.

i18n is defined in manifest.json and the key I want to use is defined in i18n.properties.

I attached the manifest.json, the i18n.properties and the annotations.xml, maybe someone here has a solution for my problem.

Thank you!

entry.title: SAP Build Appsの「Repeat with」の使い方とポイント
entry.content:
SAP BTP Hackathon 2025が無事終了しました。ご参加いただいた皆様、ありがとうございました。毎年多くの方にご参加いただき、今年も大変盛り上がりました。
毎年参加チーム数や提出作品のレベルが上がっており、運営側としては嬉しい悲鳴でした。

 

その中で、今年はSAP Build Appsの「Repeat with」の使い方についてのご質問が多かったように思えましたので、使い方とポイントを解説したいと思います。

 

「Repeat with」機能とは？

「Repeat with」機能はUIデザイン上で同じコンポーネントを繰り返し使用するための機能です。例えば、リストやテーブルなど、同じ形式のデータを複数表示する場合に非常に便利です。
「同じコンポーネント」というのは、例えばテキストやImageなどのUI要素のことを指します。

これらのUI要素のRepreat withプロパティに「内部がオブジェクトになっているリスト型変数」をバインドすることにより、そのオブジェクトに残像のようなエフェクトが付きます。

「内部がオブジェクトになっているリスト型変数」とはSAP Build AppsのVariable上で以下のような定義の変数を指します。


変数定義としてはList型であり、その中のItemのタイプとしてObject型、そのオブジェクト型の中にTextや数値型などのプロパティを含んでいる構造です。これはJSONで記述すると以下のようなものになります。

[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Alice",
    "contact": {
      "email": "alice@example.com",
      "phone": "123-456-7890"
    }
  },
  {
    "id": 2,
    "name": "Bob",
    "contact": {
      "email": "bob@example.com",
      "phone": "098-765-4321"
    }
  }
]

実行時にRepeat withで繰り返し表示がされる回数は与えたリスト型の変数の要素数（長さ、Length）に依存します。例えば、5つの要素を持つリスト型の変数を指定すると、5回繰り返し表示されます。
 

使い方

上に挙げたJSONのデータを利用してみます。このJSONのデータ形式をSAP Build Apps上で表現すると下記のような変数になります。

JSONの値をこの変数に代入して、Repeat withで使用してみます。

Repeat withにSampleListをバインドします。このHeadLineアイテムのContent（表示内容）にnameのデータを表示したいと思います。HeadLineアイテムのContentのアイコンをクリックし


Data Items in repeatをクリックし、

Currentをクリックするとウインドウ下部に展開されます。

"current"は現在の行を意味し、その中のどれをContentにバインドするか？ということです。nameを選択します。
プレビュー実行してみます。

このように一つのHeadLineアイテムが勝手にリピートされ、バインドしたリスト型の変数の要素（行）を繰り返し、その現在行に応じたデータを表示してくれます。これがRepeat withの機能です。

更に実践

このRepeat withできる要素にはRowやContainer等複数のUI要素をまとめる機能を持ったコンポーネントも含まれます。
Rowコンポーネント中にはCellが含まれていて横に並ぶようになっています。このRowコンポーネントを縦に並べると表のようなものが出来上がりますね。Rowコンポーネントを4セル設定にして、各セルにTextコンポーネントを配置し、Rowコンポーネント自体にRepeat withで変数を設定して各セルにid,name,email,phoneのプロパティをバインドさせた例がこちらです。

Rowコンポーネントのスタイルを変更して枠線を追加すれば表になるなということがわかるかと思います。

ちなみに、ROWコンポーネントのCellに対してRepeat withで変数をバインドすると、


Listの要素数分横に並べるということも出来ます。

Listの要素数（行数）が多いので表示される行数を絞りたいという場合は変数操作が必要です。Repeat withでバインドする際にFormulaを使用して式の形でバインドすると良いでしょう。例えば

SELECT関数を使用するとリスト型変数から要素の範囲を絞ったものを抜き出すことが出来ます。

例1：　　SELECT(appVars.SampleList, index <10)
→ リストの先頭10件　（リストは0から開始します。）
例2：　　SELECT(appVars.SampleList, index >= 10 && index < 20)
→リストの11件目から20件目まで

応用すればページ表示のようなことも出来ますね。

画面の表示される範囲を制御したいという場合はRepeat withするコンポーネントをScroll Viewコンポーネントの中に配置すると良いでしょう。

そうするとScroll View側のスタイルの設定で、Scroll View内で表示されることになります。

Repeat withは必要な回数分UIコンポーネントを繰り返し表示できる便利な機能です。是非使いこなしてください。

entry.title: New custom field in Fiori-App F0711
entry.content:
Hello there!

I have a custom z-field in table KNB1 which is available to use in the "dynamic selections" tab in transaction "FBL5N" (Customer Line Item Display). I now want said field to be available in Fiori-App F0711  but I am not quite sure how to do this.

Is this achievable by using the "Custom Fields and Logic" (F1481) App or what is the best way to do this?

Thank you in advance for any advice 🙂

entry.title: Re: Display only for tcode ob08
entry.content: Not sure, whether you discussed this requirement with your Security team, before posting here.   Go to transaction PFCG and open the role assigned to the user. In the Authorization tab, locate object S_TABU_DIS. Set Activity = 03 (Display only). Authorization Group = FC32 (for exchange rate tables like V_TCURR)

entry.title: Re: Display only for tcode ob08
entry.content:
Hi,

 

similar question has been asked already:https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/is-there-a-display-version-of-trxn-ob08-or-s-bce-68000174/qaq-p/5841568

 

 

So run transaction code SU53, use the object S_TABU_DIS from the transaction OB08.

 

Best,

Edrilan Berisha

entry.title: Re: The E in Event-Driven Architecture: Introducing SAP’s new Event-Add for ERP
entry.content:
Hi @vbalko-claimate, 

the news is in respect to the "new" Event Add-On for ERP and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. This is an additional offering which we did not have before. To be very clear: the Event Add-On for ERP is geared towards AEM and requires AEM.

There are no changes for SAP Event Mesh / EMIS in respect to the "original" ASAPIO add-on / Event Enablement Add-On. 

Best,

Karsten

entry.title: Real-Time Sales Data Integration with Emarsys Predict Using SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog explores how SAP Integration Suite can be used to send real-time sales data from a commerce system to Emarsys Predict Data Source, enabling Smart Insights to function seamlessly. We'll walk through the integration flow, highlight key and payload structures.

Business Scenario

Let’s consider a retail brand, which wants to send real-time online sales data to Emarsys for Smart Insights. The goal is to capture customer purchase behavior immediately after a transaction and feed it into Emarsys Predict.

Architecture Overview

The integration flow involves:

  1. Source System: Commerce platform generating sales orders.
  2. SAP Integration Suite: Middleware to transform and route data.
  3. Emarsys Predict API: Destination for real-time transactional data.

Integration Flow:

In our integration flow (iFlow), we implemented a real-time sales data pipeline to Emarsys Predict using SAP Integration Suite. Here's a high-level overview of the steps involved, which can be customized based on specific business requirements:

  1. JSON to XML Conversion:
    We began by adding a JSON to XML Converter, setting the root element as "salesOrder" to structure the incoming data appropriately.

  2. Message Mapping:
    A Message Mapping step was introduced where we:

    • Uploaded the input.XSD (representing the incoming XML structure).
    • Uploaded the output.XSD (representing the desired XML format for Emarsys).
    • Applied necessary node functions and custom functions to transform the data.
    • Mapped key fields such as Email and Order ID, using "one as many" logic to loop through order items.

  3. XML to CSV Conversion:
    The transformed XML was then passed through an XML to CSV Converter.

  4. Content Modifier & API Call:
    We used a Content Modifier to add the required CSV headers, followed by a Request-Reply step to send the final payload to the Emarsys Sales API.

    Request Reply - HTTP Adapter Configuration:

Emarsys Sales API Details: Uploading your sales data 

 Sample Input Payload:

{
    "user": "RetailStore",
    "id": "403509910",
    "transType": "SALES_ORDER",
    "transDate": "20230524",
    "transTime": "12:41:56+00:00",
    "marketingArea": "STORE",
    "storeId": "store_gb",

entry.title: Re: The system did not generate the right dunning level a...
entry.content:
Dear Bhawesh,

Thank you for your comment. I would like to know why the system did not display the corresponding dunning level as set after the "dunning run".

Original configuration settings:

L1 : Days in arrears >=7

L2 : Days in arrears >=14

L3 : Days in arrears >=21

L4 : Days in arrears >=28

No grace period

The current outstanding items = 18. After the dunning process, the dunning level should correspond to L2, but why does the system only correspond to L1?

entry.title: Update MWSKZ (TAX CODE) in ME21N
entry.content:
Hello everyone, I need help updating mswkz when creating a purchase order in ME21N. The EKPO-MWSKZ field needs to be updated when a partner is added to the header partner tab, but in the BAdI ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST , the PROCESS_ITEM method is not called when a partner is modified or added , and I haven't found any other solutions to update EKPO through another method, as the check method does not allow set_data. I tried the FM MEPOITEM in the check method to call the process_item method again, the field is correctly updated on the screen but in EKPO the field mwskz is not updated.

Thank you, Best regards

entry.title: Re: Dunning notices will not print
entry.content: For information, even if Output Parameter Determination (OPD) is configured to email you, SAP checks the customer master data first. For dunning notices, the system uses the clerk email address from the company code level of the customer master. If that’s blank, it falls back to the general email address. Go to that BP and verify the clerk email address under the Correspondence tab for the customer is valid email id and matches what OPD expects

entry.title: Re: How we can capture the number of shares/options (stoc...
entry.content:
Hi @Harshihash_0306 

For this requirement, we created a MDF object named "Insider Stock" and started capturing the update, with basic information like Stock Allocation date, Number of stocks, unit value of the stock. 

For ESS, it is just a view access and from backend admin will upload information based on the confirmation received from Compensation team. 

Thanks

Arun Suresh

entry.title: Re: Update MWSKZ (TAX CODE) in ME21N
entry.content: Please share more information on what the Business requirement is.  In SAP, many workarounds are there for one requirement or issue and sometimes, via standard configuration itself, you can achieve this.  You need to ensure, whatever you consider is the Best Practice approach

entry.title: Re: Variant Matching doesn't scrap material flagged for d...
entry.content: Thanks for your insight. Unfortunately, this confirms that there's no standard solution to exclude obsolete materials, and that I have to resort to tricks to overcome the problem, such as the one you suggested. This involves adding a ZOBSOLETE_FLAG feature to the configurable class, which is obviously correct, but forces me to add it to thousands of obsolete materials.

entry.title: CC cost allocation will be done for the costs remaining at CC level AFTER the timesheet cost posting
entry.content:
Hi Team,
Business observed an issue with the cost center (CC) allocation behavior in our S/4HANA Public Cloud system. The system is currently allocating the entire CC-level cost, without considering the timesheet cost postings that have already been transferred from the cost center to the WBS elements via secondary cost elements.

 

Issue Details: When timesheet entries are posted, the system creates: Credit on the Cost Center (CC) using secondary GL accounts Debit on the WBS element However, during CC allocation, the system continues to allocate the full CC-level cost, ignoring the fact that part of this cost has already been transferred to WBS via timesheets.

Expected Behavior: We expect that the CC allocation should only allocate the remaining balance on the CC after the timesheet cost postings. In other words, it should exclude the portion of the cost that has already been moved to WBS elements via secondary cost postings.

 

We have attached a screenshot comparing the expected result vs. the current system behavior, clearly showing the discrepancy.

 

Could you please analyze and confirm: Why the allocation is including the entire CC-level cost, ignoring timesheet postings? How we can configure the system to allocate only the net CC cost after timesheet postings? 

 

Expected result:         
           
   Primary GL 1  Primary GL 2  Primary GL 3  Total  WA of WBS codes based on YTD amounts USD  Weight  
 CC level initial balance                 1 000,00                    500,00                 2 000,00    3 500,00 WBS 1   10 000,00         0,45 
       WBS 2     5 000,00         0,23 
Step 1Timsheet cost posting Secondary GL 1  Secondary GL 2  Secondary GL 3   WBS 3     7 000,00         0,32 
 CC level                  (600,00)                  (250,00)               (1 500,00)   (2 350,00)     22 000,00  
 WBS level                    600,00                    250,00                 1 500,00    2 350,00     
           
 CC level after timesheet cost posting                    400,00                    250,00                    500,00    1 150,00 --> balance to be allocated (CC cost allocation)   
           
Step 2CC Cost allocation to WBS                  (400,00)                  (250,00)                  (500,00)   (1 150,00)     
 WBS 1                    181,82                    113,64                    227,27        522,73     
 WBS 2                      90,91                      56,82                    113,64        261,36     
 WBS 3                    127,27                      79,55                    159,09        365,91     
     ctrl                 -       

 

Current system behavior:             
               
   Primary GL 1  Primary GL 2  Primary GL 3  Total  WA of WBS codes based on YTD amounts USD  Weight      
 CC level initial balance                 1 000,00                    500,00                 2 000,00    3 500,00 WBS 1   10 000,00         0,45     
       WBS 2     5 000,00         0,23     
Step 1Timsheet cost posting Secondary GL 1  Secondary GL 2  Secondary GL 3   WBS 3     7 000,00         0,32     
 CC level                  (600,00)                  (250,00)               (1 500,00)   (2 350,00)     22 000,00      
 WBS level                    600,00                    250,00                 1 500,00    2 350,00         
               
 CC level after timesheet cost posting                1 000,00                    500,00                2 000,00    3 500,00 --> over allocation due to CC balance not taking into consideration the timesheet cost posting.  
               
Step 2CC Cost allocation to WBS               (1 000,00)                  (500,00)               (2 000,00)   (3 500,00)         
 WBS 1                    454,55                    227,27                    909,09    1 590,91         
 WBS 2                    227,27                    113,64                    454,55        795,45         
 WBS 3                    318,18                    159,09                    636,36    1 113,64         
     ctrl                 -           
               



Regards,
Suvarna.

entry.title: Re: custom field creation for work center maintenance planning
entry.content:
Hi Expert's ,

Requirement: Users want a creation date of maintenance Order as filter option in Work Center Utilization 

where he can able to fetch all the maintenance order created on particular date.

For this I have created a custom Field (Creation Date) using Custom Field App and have enabled it for UI interface " Manage Work Center Utilization" . 

 

Now we can able to view the field in filter options , but when we provide any input like to fetch all order of today , we are getting output as "No Data".

 

I searched for BADI's which are helpful in providing values for extension field's but could not find.

Thanks & regards

habeeb

entry.title: Re: Variant Matching doesn't scrap material flagged for d...
entry.content: If the data is more and if you feel, it will be a challenge, what you can do is maintain some common (dummy) value in the material master in any of the unused fields. Maintain a variable in TVARVC table for this value, material code and add additionally whatever fields you want to validate. With this, as and when, users execute tcode like va01 (as you indicated), system should, in the backend compare this via mv45afzz and if matches, ignore that entry or trigger an error message. With this approach, you are not hard coding the logic and for any reasons, if Business wants to remove or add any entry, the users can do so via sm30. No need to depend on ABAP team for code change

entry.title: Routing and Alternative BOM issue
entry.content:
Hi Experts,
I have an issue in routing. I have one DM code which has 2 different bom. The difference is just 1 different item. Alternative 1 hasnt "Deactive yeast", alternative 2 has. And this product producing on 2 different line. So I have 2 different routing. When I open component allocation for routing 1, there is no issue. System is taking bom alternative 1. But When I open second routing, system is look like taking alternative bom 2 but I can not find my different item. "Deactive yeast" is not showing. So system can not find actually alternative 2. I looked everywhere I checked every blog, GPT I think whole Internet enviroment and I couldn solve it. By the way also there 2 different prod version for DM, VM and PM. Can you help me please ?
Thank you.

entry.title: Sale price record VK11 upto 5 decimals
entry.content:
Hello Everyone, As per SAP standards, the system allows up to 2 decimals in the price record, but our requirement is to have up to 5 decimals. For such cases, SAP’s recommendation is to maintain the record using units like per 10PC, 100PC, etc. However, we have encountered situations where human errors in performing these calculations have resulted in significant revenue discrepancies. Hence, I would like to understand if we have any SAP recommendation.

Proposed a solution to have additional columns in standard mass sales price app where you will enter price upto 5 digits and system does automatic calculation to put upto 2 decimals (attached PP for your reference).

we also thought of duplicating and creating new custom currency type that allows more decimal places. But we have already gone live with 3 sites and implementing this would cause inconsistencies.
